description: Monitors application performance metrics, identifies bottlenecks, and provides optimization recommendations
author: JSONbored
useCases: Monitor API response times and identify slow endpoints
Track memory usage and detect potential memory leaks
Analyze database query performance and optimization opportunities
Monitor Web Vitals (LCP, FID, CLS) for frontend performance
Set up automated performance testing in CI/CD pipelines
Generate comprehensive performance reports with actionable insights
Monitor infrastructure resources (CPU, memory, disk usage)
Analyze bundle sizes and identify large dependencies
Set up performance alerts for threshold breaches

hookConfig.scriptContent:
#!/bin/bash

echo "ðŸ” Performance Monitor - Analyzing system performance..."

# Performance monitoring areas
echo "ðŸ“Š Monitoring Areas:"
echo "  â€¢ Application Performance Metrics"
echo "  â€¢ Database Performance"
echo "  â€¢ Frontend Performance (Web Vitals)"
echo "  â€¢ Infrastructure Monitoring"
echo "  â€¢ Automated Performance Testing"

# Check if performance tools are available
command -v node >/dev/null 2>&1 && echo "âœ“ Node.js available for performance profiling"
command -v lighthouse >/dev/null 2>&1 && echo "âœ“ Lighthouse available for web performance"
command -v artillery >/dev/null 2>&1 && echo "âœ“ Artillery available for load testing"

# System performance check
echo ""
echo "ðŸ’» System Performance:"

# Memory usage
if command -v free >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    mem_usage=$(free | grep Mem | awk '{printf "%.2f", $3/$2 * 100.0}')
    echo "  Memory Usage: ${mem_usage}%"
    if (( $(echo "$mem_usage > 85" | bc -l) 2>/dev/null )); then
        echo "  ðŸš¨ High memory usage detected!"
    fi
fi

# Disk usage
disk_usage=$(df / | tail -1 | awk '{print $5}' | sed 's/%//')
echo "  Disk Usage: ${disk_usage}%"
if (( disk_usage > 90 )); then
    echo "  ðŸš¨ High disk usage detected!"
fi

# Load average
if command -v uptime >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    load_avg=$(uptime | awk -F'load average:' '{print $2}' | awk '{print $1}' | sed 's/,//')
    echo "  Load Average: $load_avg"
fi

# Performance monitoring recommendations
echo ""
echo "ðŸ’¡ Performance Recommendations:"
echo "  â€¢ Implement response time tracking for API endpoints"
echo "  â€¢ Set up Web Vitals monitoring for frontend performance"
echo "  â€¢ Monitor database query performance"
echo "  â€¢ Set up automated performance testing"
echo "  â€¢ Configure performance alerts and thresholds"
echo "  â€¢ Use profiling tools for bottleneck identification"
echo "  â€¢ Implement performance budgets for builds"

echo ""
echo "ðŸ“‹ Next Steps:"
echo "  1. Set up performance monitoring dashboards"
echo "  2. Configure performance alerts"
echo "  3. Implement automated performance testing"
echo "  4. Review and optimize identified bottlenecks"

echo ""
echo "ðŸŽ¯ Performance monitor analysis complete!"

exit 0

troubleshooting.issue: Memory usage calculation fails on macOS systems
troubleshooting.solution: Hook uses free command which is Linux-only. On macOS, install free via brew install free or modify hook to use vm_stat | grep 'Pages active' for memory statistics instead.

troubleshooting.issue: bc command not found error on minimal systems
troubleshooting.solution: Install bc for floating-point arithmetic (apt-get install bc or brew install bc). Alternatively, modify memory comparison to use integer math with awk instead of bc -l for percentage checks.

troubleshooting.issue: Lighthouse or Artillery tools not detected
troubleshooting.solution: Install globally with npm install -g lighthouse @artillery/core or install locally and modify hook to check npx lighthouse and npx artillery instead of direct commands.

troubleshooting.issue: Hook shows same performance data every run
troubleshooting.solution: This is a stop hook providing system snapshot at session end. For continuous monitoring, integrate with dedicated APM tools or add timestamped logging to track changes over multiple sessions.

troubleshooting.issue: Load average shows very high values but system responsive
troubleshooting.solution: Load average is relative to CPU core count. Value of 8 is normal for 8-core system. Divide load average by core count (sysctl -n hw.ncpu on macOS, nproc on Linux) for actual load percentage.
